physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Presented with a serum calcium level of 15.3 mg/dl, severe hypercalciuria, and bilateral nephrocalcinosis. No significant past medical history. Mild irritability, increased urination, and refusal of solid foods.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Gradual improvement of hypercalcemia after management with fluids and diuretics, and low-calcium formula.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Serum calcium confirmed at 16.3 mg/dl upon admission. Severe hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis were noted.
Started on a supplement of 400 IU of vitamin D daily.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Improvement noted with serum calcium dropping to 10.6 mg/dl.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Normalization of calcium levels with serum calcium now at 10.4 mg/dl.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Continued improvement with a declining trend in serum calcium levels.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: 24,25(OH)2D undetectable at this age while 25-hydroxyvitamin D is normal.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: No change in 24,25(OH)2D levels noted, suggesting persistence of metabolic impairment despite stable calcium levels.
